p: Malaysia has experienced an exponential increase in dengue cases despite having well-established dengue control measures. The dengue incidence in Malaysia increased precipitously from 31.6 cases/100 000 in 2000 to 361 cases/100 000 in 2014, i.e. an 11-fold rise [ 4]. Environmental changes such as rising temperatures, increased rainfall, accelerated urbanization and industrialization, population growth, and poor waste and water management, which leads to the proliferation of mosquito species ( Aedes aegypti and A. albopictus) that transmit DENV, are all possible reasons for the upsurge of dengue cases [ 4– 6].
